title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What area of mathematics is used in weather forecasts, sports predictions, and setting auto insurance rates?

options.label: A
options.text: Algebra

options.label: B
options.text: Geometry

options.label: C
options.text: Probability

options.label: D
options.text: Statistics

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of getting a perfect score by randomly guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
According to the fundamental counting principle, if there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are:

options.label: A
options.text: A + B ways to pair the outcomes

options.label: B
options.text: A times B ways to pair the outcomes

options.label: C
options.text: A minus B ways to pair the outcomes

options.label: D
options.text: A divided by B ways to pair the outcomes

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected average score if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz?
If there are 20 questions and five possible answers for each question, what is the probability that you would get all 20 questions correct by randomly guessing?

options.label: D
options.text: 1 in 95 trillion

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the most common score if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz?

options.label: A
options.text: Exactly 5 out of 10

options.label: B
options.text: Not exactly 5 out of 10

options.label: C
options.text: A score of 0

options.label: D
options.text: A score of 10

multiple-choice.question: What is the number of possible outcomes for a 10-question true/false quiz, where each question has two possible answers?
What is the probability of getting a question right by guessing, where there are five possible answers for each question?
If you were to always randomly guess at every question on a 10-question true/false quiz, what would be the average number of the number of questions you would get right?
What is the number of possible outcomes for a 20-question true/false quiz, where each question has five possible answers?
What type of narrative connects people and makes a story timeless and humanistic?

options.label: A
options.text: Personal story of facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: personal story

options.label: C
options.text: official story

options.label: D
options.text: authentic narrative

multiple-choice.question: What are the three components of the trifecta of sourcing in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: official sources, unofficial sources, and data sources

options.label: B
options.text: official sources, unofficial sources, and experts

options.label: C
options.text: overview sources, unofficial sources, and academics

options.label: D
options.text: official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

multiple-choice.question: What type of sources provide knowledge of the big picture and are not directly connected as stakeholders?

options.label: A
options.text: unofficial sources

options.label: B
options.text: official sources

options.label: C
options.text: experts

options.label: D
options.text: overview sources

multiple-choice.question: How do you identify what is compelling from what is chatter in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: By presenting bulleted facts and updates

options.label: B
options.text: By using official sources

options.label: C
options.text: By using overview sources

options.label: D
options.text: By asking surprising questions

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary role of unofficial sources in a well-reported piece of journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide the big picture

options.label: B
options.text: To provide the numbers

options.label: C
options.text: To provide the answers

options.label: D
options.text: To provide the why

multiple-choice.question: What is the key benefit of asking surprising questions in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey information quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To use official sources

options.label: C
options.text: To present bulleted facts and updates

options.label: D
options.text: To achieve the complicated, fragile human connection

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of anecdote in a story?

options.label: A
options.text: An anecdote is a type of official source

options.label: B
options.text: An anecdote is a type of overview source

options.label: C
options.text: An anecdote is a type of unofficial source

options.label: D
options.text: An anecdote is oxygen that breathes life into a grey story of exposition, facts, and data

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of narrative personal stories in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To present bulleted facts and updates

options.label: B
options.text: To convey information quickly

options.label: C
options.text: To make the journalism memorable and deliver the narrative bond that will connect us to each other

options.label: D
options.text: To use official sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the key difference between a situation that requires a slow dance of information and one that requires quick action?

options.label: A
options.text: A situation that requires a slow dance of information is urgent and requires action now

options.label: B
options.text: A situation that requires a slow dance of information is not urgent and does not require action now

options.label: C
options.text: A situation that requires a slow dance of information is a narrative personal story

options.label: D
options.text: A situation that requires a slow dance of information is a type of unofficial source

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of regarding the stories of every subject as sacred in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To use official sources

options.label: B
options.text: To present bulleted facts and updates

options.label: C
options.text: To achieve the complicated, fragile human connection

options.label: D
options.text: To convey information quickly

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

options.label: C
options.text: Samuel Richardson

options.label: D
options.text: Mark Twain

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: A love story between two upper-class characters

options.label: B
options.text: A love story between a poor, serving-class heroine and an upper-class suitor

options.label: C
options.text: A story about class and marriage

options.label: D
options.text: A story about women and men

options.text: By inspiring their theories

options.label: C
options.text: By shaping their ability to change a person's point of view

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: That humans are adapted to change

options.label: D
options.text: That humans are solitary heroes

options.label: B
options.text: That we are not members of a shared quest

options.label: C
options.text: That we are not adapted to change

options.label: D
options.text: That we are not solitary heroes

options.label: A

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: "The number times the base equals the power"

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What is the first form of telling time mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Mechanical clock

options.label: B
options.text: Sundial

options.label: C
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: D
options.text: Atomic clock

multiple-choice.question: Which device was used to estimate the passage of time by burning down at a fairly predictable speed?

options.label: A
options.text: Candle

options.label: B
options.text: Stick of incense

options.label: C
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: D
options.text: Sundial

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for scientific time today?

options.label: A
options.text: Sundials

options.label: B
options.text: Mechanical clocks

options.label: C
options.text: Atomic clocks

options.label: D
options.text: Hourglasses

multiple-choice.question: Why does it matter that we keep track of time?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to communicate with people all over the world

options.label: B
options.text: It makes it possible to accurately predict the weather

options.label: C
options.text: It helps us to understand the universe

options.label: D
options.text: It makes it possible to accurately communicate with people all over the world and to coordinate activities

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the region on earth that has a uniform standard time?

options.label: A
options.text: Time zone

options.label: B
options.text: Sundial zone

options.label: C
options.text: Atomic zone

options.label: D
options.text: Clock zone

multiple-choice.question: How many time zones are there on land?

options.label: C
options.text: 24 * 40 / 60 = 40 (since the 24 time zones used internationally are not all on land)

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate time difference between New York and Boston?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 hour

options.label: B
options.text: 2 hours

options.label: C
options.text: 8 minutes

options.label: D
options.text: 1 day

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the use of time zones?

options.label: A
options.text: To make communication more difficult

options.label: B
options.text: To make it easier to understand the universe

options.label: C
options.text: To make it possible to accurately communicate with people all over the world and to coordinate activities

options.label: D
options.text: To make it easier to predict the weather

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the device that was commonly used on board ships to estimate the passage of time?

options.label: A
options.text: Sundial

options.label: B
options.text: Candle

options.label: C
options.text: Stick of incense

options.label: D
options.text: Hourglass

options.text: Gnomon

options.label: B
options.text: Sundial

options.label: C
options.text: Hourglass

options.label: D
